instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Probing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> makes SMC reset
threads.message:
I got this liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.

History is minor liquid spill around <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>. Was not starting. After UC starts when plugin in power supply.

Now when I push pwr on keyboard it immediately resets smc (charger goes green and machine reboots). Also as soon as I put the test-probe on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> it initiates the smc reset (goes green and reboots). <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.12V

I changed <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> but still the same issue.

What to do now ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Probing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> makes SMC reset
threads.message: Usually trackpad or cable/connector issue. Pin 18 on J4800 is SMC reset line combined with the power switch. I say probably corrosion on the cable/connector/trackpad. In a rare case it could be the keyboard but then the left CRTL,ALT,SHIFT would also not function.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Probing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> makes SMC reset
threads.message:
Thanks Duke.

But with board out and keyboard connector removed it stills resets the smc when probing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

Why?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Probing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> makes SMC reset
threads.message: Cause your multimeter is loading it down. Is this an el cheapo meter? But has nothing to do with the trackpad/keyboard issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Probing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> makes SMC reset
threads.message:
It's a Fluke 125 Scopemeter (~2000 USD). Hmmmm.

Normally I can measure <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> without problems

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Probing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> makes SMC reset
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Probing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> makes SMC reset
threads.message: No but it measured a little bit low (48K). I switched it now measures 99K
